conclusion: To determine the magnitude of the velocity v of the ions after passing through the velocity selector and the charge-to-mass ratio of the ions selected by the magnetic analyzer, we need to analyze each step in the process.
In the velocity selector, the ions experience both an electric field E and a magnetic field B.
The ions will travel in a straight line through the selector if the forces from the electric and magnetic fields balance each other.
The electric force is given by F_electric = qE.
The magnetic force is given by F_magnetic = qvB.
For the ions to pass through the velocity selector without deflection, qE = qvB.
Solving for v gives v = E/B.
In the magnetic analyzer, the ions move in a circular path with a radius R.
The magnetic force provides the centripetal force for this circular motion.
The equation qvB = mv^2/R describes the centripetal force.
Using v = E/B from the velocity selector, substitute to get q(E/B)B = mv^2/R.
Solving for the charge-to-mass ratio q/m gives q/m = E/RB^2.
The radius R of the circular motion is determined by the path the ions take through the magnetic analyzer.
The ions follow a trajectory from point M to point N, forming a quarter-circle path.
The radius R is the average of the inner and outer radii of the analyzer, R = (R1 + R2)/2.
Magnitude of Velocity v is v = E/B.
Charge-to-Mass Ratio q/m is q/m = 2E/(R1 + R2)B^2.
Conclusion: The velocity of the ions after passing through the velocity selector is E/B, and the charge-to-mass ratio of the ions selected by the magnetic analyzer is 2E/(R1 + R2)B^2.
